neighbors.name: Luther, Roger & Jennifer
neighbors.claims: Roger K. Luther and Jennifer K. Luther are long-time residents of Orleans, Nebraska, where they are active parishioners at St. Mary's Catholic Church ([Lincoln Diocese](https://www.lincolndiocese.org/news/diocesan-news/17299-parishioners-to-celebrate-125th-anniversary-of-their-parish-home)). Jennifer Luther actively supports local youth programs, specifically sponsoring awards for the Harlan County 4-H Ambassadors ([UNL Extension](https://extension.unl.edu/statewide/harlan/4-h/4-h-ambassadors/)). They have not been publicly noted in local meetings or news reports about development issues, indicating no clear stance on such projects.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Jennifer through her community interests (4-H, church). Acknowledge her long-standing family ties to the area and emphasize how the project supports the next generation of local agriculture, aligning with her support for 4-H.

citations.claim: Active parishioners at St. Mary's Catholic Church
citations.title: Parishioners to celebrate 125th anniversary of their parish home

citations.claim: Jennifer Luther sponsors 4-H Ambassador awards
citations.title: Harlan County 4-H Ambassadors

neighbors.name: Stoelting, James
neighbors.claims: James Stoelting is a registered landowner in Orleans, Nebraska, holding water rights for irrigation ([NE DNR](https://nednr.nebraska.gov/dynamic/WaterRights/WaterRights/ContactLandingPage?contactId=143048)). He is listed as a recipient of federal farm subsidies ([Starving Farmer](https://www.starvingfarmer.com/county/083/31)). While a Dan Stoelting serves on the Harlan County Planning Commission ([Harlan County](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/pdfs/planning_zoning/Planning%20Commission%20Members.pdf)), there is no record of James Stoelting participating in public hearings or making statements on local land development.
neighbors.influence_justification: Local landowner; no known public office

approach_recommendations.engage: Contact directly with specific details on irrigation and soil protection. Clarify he is distinct from Planning Commissioner Dan Stoelting to avoid procedural confusion.

citations.claim: Holds water rights for irrigation
citations.title: State of Nebraska DWEE - Contact Information

citations.claim: Recipient of federal farm subsidies
citations.title: Farmers in Harlan County Nebraska

citations.claim: Dan Stoelting serves on Planning Commission
citations.title: Harlan County Planning Commission Members

neighbors.name: Lewis, Marlen L. & Beverly E.
neighbors.claims: Marlen L. Lewis is a resident of Orleans, Nebraska, and the proprietor of Lewis Produce, a local business participating in regional farmers' markets ([NE Dept of Agriculture](http://govdocs.nebraska.gov/epubs/A5150/D008-2013.pdf)). He has been listed as a treasurer for local entities ([Broker Snapshot](https://brokersnapshot.com/Company?dot=975311&prefix=MC&docket=1026106)). There is no public record of the Lewises taking a stance on renewable energy projects.
neighbors.influence_justification: Local business owner (Lewis Produce); no civic role

approach_recommendations.engage: Meet face-to-face, acknowledging his role in the local food economy (Lewis Produce). Emphasize how the project respects agricultural land use and offers stability for local landowners.

citations.claim: Proprietor of Lewis Produce
citations.title: Nebraska Department of Agriculture Produce Growers

citations.claim: Listed as treasurer for local entities
citations.title: Broker Snapshot - Marlen Lewis

neighbors.name: Beau Martin & Jessica Martin
neighbors.claims: Beau Martin is an Orleans-area farmer and auctioneer who operates Martin Auction Co. with his father, Lyle Martin ([Martin Auction Co.](https://martin-auctionco.com/aboutus.html)). He received approximately $46,691 in USDA farm subsidies from 1995 to 2024 ([EWG Farm Subsidy Database](https://farm.ewg.org/addrsearch.php?page=3&z=1&zip=68966)). Jessica Martin is listed as a co-owner of a horse with Beau Martin ([Nebraska RHA](https://nebraskarha.org/ultimate-auction/jm-rowdy-blue-leo/)). No public records were found of Beau or Jessica Martin speaking in local meetings regarding the Harlan County wind/solar moratoriums discussed in 2023-2024 ([Harlan County Minutes](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/posting_files/pdfs/board/minutes/2023/20230418_101136_board_minutes.pdf)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Leverage his role as a local auctioneer and business owner. Approach with a focus on economic opportunities for the local community and respect for agricultural operations. His business background suggests he may value clear, fair contracting terms.

citations.claim: Operates Martin Auction Co. with his father
citations.title: Martin Auction Co. About Us

citations.claim: Received USDA farm subsidies
citations.title: EWG Farm Subsidy Database

citations.claim: Jessica Martin co-owner
citations.title: Nebraska RHA Auction Listing

citations.claim: No speaking record in minutes
citations.title: Harlan County Board Minutes April 2023

neighbors.name: Carol A. Wells
neighbors.claims: Carol A. Wells was an absentee landowner who lived in Grand Island and passed away on October 31, 2021, at age 88 ([Apfel Funeral Home](https://www.apfelfuneralhome.com/obituaries/carol-a-wells)). She maintained her primary residence outside Harlan County, and her estate or heirs (children Susan Vigil and Jay Wells) likely manage the property interests now ([Apfel Funeral Home](https://www.apfelfuneralhome.com/obituaries/carol-a-wells)). There is no record of her involvement in recent Harlan County development discussions.

approach_recommendations.engage: Contact the heirs (Susan Vigil or Jay Wells) regarding the estate's land management goals. Focus on asset preservation and minimal disruption to the property's value or future transferability.

citations.claim: Passed away October 31, 2021
citations.title: Obituary for Carol A. Wells

neighbors.name: Bart A. Woodward & Jill R. Woodward
neighbors.claims: Bart A. Woodward is a professional Associate Broker and Certified General Appraiser with Agri Affiliates, Inc., based in Kearney, NE ([Agri Affiliates](https://agriaffiliates.com/agents/bart-woodward-ara/)). He and his wife, Jill R. Woodward, reside in Minden (Kearney County), where Jill is identified as his spouse in family obituaries ([Ludvigsen Mortuary](https://www.ludvigsenmortuary.com/memorialpage.asp?id=2533)). Bart Woodward specializes in agricultural real estate sales and management, indicating a professional interest in land value and usage ([Agri Affiliates](https://agriaffiliates.com/agents/bart-woodward-ara/)). No public statements regarding the Harlan County renewable moratorium were found.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Bart Woodward as an industry professional. He will likely have a sophisticated understanding of land valuation, leases, and contracts. Focus on the financial specifics, decommissioning assurances, and how the project impacts long-term land value.

citations.claim: Associate Broker and Appraiser at Agri Affiliates
citations.title: Agri Affiliates Agent Profile: Bart Woodward

citations.claim: Jill R. Woodward identified as spouse
citations.title: Obituary for Joel Walter Marreel

neighbors.name: Jesse R. Hays & Jill C. Hays
neighbors.claims: Jesse R. Hays is an Orleans-area resident who has worked in construction, including as a framer for Cedar Creek Construction, and has identified as a small business owner ([Bold.pro Resume](https://ne.bold.pro/my/jesse-haysres)). He held a Nebraska contractor’s license (No. 19341) ([BuildZoom](https://www.buildzoom.com/contractor/jesse-hays)). There are no public records of the Hays couple taking positions on development or participating in county meetings related to land use.

approach_recommendations.engage: Highlight potential benefits to the local economy and opportunities for local trades when communicating with the Hays household. Discussing potential construction-related economic spinoffs may align with his professional background.

citations.claim: Small business owner and construction background
citations.title: Jesse Hays Resume

citations.claim: Nebraska contractor license
citations.title: BuildZoom Contractor Profile

neighbors.name: Gary L. Stoelting & James G. Stoelting
neighbors.claims: Gary L. Stoelting and James G. Stoelting are brothers and part of a long-standing farm family in the Orleans area, confirmed by the obituary of their brother John A. Stoelting ([Valley Voice](https://www.valleyvoicene.com/news/john-stoelting)). The Stoelting Farms operation is active in Harlan County, receiving significant USDA subsidies, including over $1.5 million for Gary Stoelting and $1.8 million for James Stoelting from 1995-2024 ([EWG Farm Subsidy Database](https://farm.ewg.org/addrsearch.php?z=1&zip=68966&page=0)). They have not publicly voiced opinions on local development in available records, but their multi-generational tenure and large-scale operation suggest they hold informal influence.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Stoeltings with respect for their family’s extensive agricultural legacy. Given the scale of their operation, they may be interested in the financial stability offered by land leases, provided it does not disrupt their core farming activities.

citations.claim: Brothers confirmed by obituary
citations.title: Obituary for John A. Stoelting

citations.claim: USDA subsidy amounts
citations.title: EWG Farm Subsidy Database

neighbors.name: William Sugimatsu Davis
neighbors.claims: Public records list William Sugimatsu Davis as a co-owner of Harlan County parcel 280002200 ([source](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/webpages/assessor/assessor.html)). William Sugimatsu Davis is listed as a graduate of the University of Nebraska Medical Center (2005) with ties to Orleans, Nebraska, located in Harlan County ([source](https://www.unmc.edu/newsroom/2005/05/04/634-unmc-students-to-receive-diplomas-in-kearney-lincoln-scottsbluff-and-omaha-at-commencements/)). No public statements on development or energy issues by Davis were found in available sources ([source](https://kearneyhub.com)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Non-resident landowner; UNMC graduate; no local roles

approach_recommendations.engage: Use formal communication emphasizing financial stability. Highlight guaranteed lease income and property value protection, as an absentee owner likely prioritizes economic benefits over local considerations.

citations.claim: Public records list William Sugimatsu Davis as a co-owner of Harlan County parcel 280002200
citations.title: Harlan County Assessor

citations.claim: William Sugimatsu Davis is listed as a graduate of the University of Nebraska Medical Center (2005) with ties to Orleans, Nebraska
citations.title: UNMC Commencement News Release

citations.claim: No public statements on development or energy issues by Davis were found in available sources
citations.title: Kearney Hub Search Results

neighbors.name: Jeremy D. VanBoening & Erin M. (Loken) VanBoening
neighbors.claims: Dr. Jeremy VanBoening and Dr. Erin VanBoening are veterinarians who moved to Harlan County in 2003 to purchase and operate the Republican Valley Animal Center in Alma ([source](https://www.repvalleyanimal.com/meet-the-staff)). Jeremy serves as the Chairman of the Harlan County Planning Commission, with a term expiring in 2027 ([source](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/pdfs/planning_zoning/Planning%20Commission%20Members.pdf)). In November 2024, Jeremy advised the County Board of Supervisors regarding wind energy generation setbacks, recommending that previously approved setbacks not be adopted pending further information gathering ([source](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/posting_files/pdfs/board/minutes/2024/20241106_164106_board_minutes.pdf)). He is actively involved in updating the Harlan County Comprehensive Plan and zoning policies ([source](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/posting_files/pdfs/board/minutes/2024/20241106_164106_board_minutes.pdf)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Planning Commission Chairman; local veterinarian; business owner

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage formally regarding zoning compliance and comprehensive plan alignment. Acknowledge his regulatory role and emphasize how the project supports county planning goals while respecting agricultural land use.

citations.claim: Dr. Jeremy VanBoening and Dr. Erin VanBoening are veterinarians who moved to Harlan County in 2003 to purchase and operate the Republican Valley Animal Center in Alma
citations.title: Republican Valley Animal Center Staff

neighbors.name: Murdoch Enterprises, Inc.
neighbors.claims: Murdoch Enterprises, Inc. is a Nebraska farm corporation based in Orleans (Harlan County), primarily engaged in agriculture. The entity has received approximately $750,399 in federal farm program payments from 1995–2024, indicating a significant long-term operational presence ([EWG Farm Subsidy Database](https://farm.ewg.org/addrsearch.php?z=1&zip=68966&page=0)). Principal Marlin Murdoch serves as the Chairman of the Lower Republican Natural Resources District (LRNRD) Board of Directors, a powerful local regulatory body ([LRNRD Board of Directors](https://lrnrd.org/about/board-of-directors)). In his capacity as LRNRD Chair, Murdoch has overseen the district's participation in the Nebraska Cooperative Republican Platte Enhancement Project (NCORPE). In July 2020, the NCORPE board voted to enter into a lease agreement with renewable energy developer Invenergy to study solar and wind resources on NCORPE property ([LRNRD Minutes Aug 2020](https://lrnrd.org/meeting/minutes/2020/817-minutes-8-13-2020/file)). Furthermore, in June 2019, the LRNRD board provided consensus that they "would like revenue from the land (renewables, grain production, and grazing) to support operational cost" ([LRNRD Minutes June 2019](https://lrnrd.org/meeting/minutes/2019/724-minutes-6-13-19/file)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Principal Marlin Murdoch is the Chairman of the Lower Republican Natural Resources District (LRNRD), a key regulatory body for land and water use. The family operation receives substantial federal subsidies ($750k+), reflecting significant agricultural standing.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Marlin Murdoch in his capacity as both a landowner and NRD Chairman. Acknowledge the NRD's pragmatic approach to renewable energy revenue (Invenergy lease) and position the project as a similar opportunity for private land stewardship and economic stability.

citations.claim: Murdoch Enterprises Inc received $750,399 in subsidies 1995-2024
citations.title: EWG Farm Subsidy Database - Orleans NE

citations.claim: Marlin Murdoch is Chair of Lower Republican NRD
citations.title: LRNRD Board of Directors

citations.claim: NCORPE board voted to lease land to Invenergy for solar/wind study
citations.title: LRNRD Board Minutes August 13 2020

citations.claim: LRNRD board consensus to seek revenue from renewables
citations.title: LRNRD Board Minutes June 13 2019

neighbors.name: James Drake Farm Enterprises LLC
neighbors.claims: James Drake Farm Enterprises LLC is an agricultural limited liability company in Harlan County, Nebraska, which received $11,313 in federal farm program payments from 1995–2024 ([EWG Farm Subsidy Database](https://farm.ewg.org/persondetail.php?custnumber=E00064398)). The entity is associated with James Drake, a local resident who also receives personal conservation payments ([EWG](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=31083&progcode=total_cr&regionname=HarlanCounty,Nebraska)). Unlike the Murdoch family, James Drake does not appear in local leadership roles or public office rosters, and no public records of involvement in development disputes or political activities were found. Note: Search results for "James Drake" in this region may conflate with unrelated individuals (e.g., a physicist or a criminal defendant in Michigan); no relevant local stance on renewable energy could be verified for this specific landowner.
neighbors.influence_justification: Small-scale farm operation with modest subsidy history ($11k for LLC). No evidence of public office, board memberships, or community leadership roles found in county records.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach James Drake personally with respect for his farming needs. Given the lack of public stance, he is likely a 'blank slate' regarding development; early, respectful engagement focusing on land preservation and economic stability (easements) is recommended to prevent default opposition.

citations.claim: James Drake Farm Enterprises LLC received $11,313 in subsidies
citations.title: EWG Farm Subsidy Detail - James Drake Farm Enterprises LLC

citations.claim: James Drake received personal conservation payments
citations.title: EWG Conservation Reserve Program Recipients

overview_summary: All three profiled neighbors have an unknown stance on the development, as none have publicly voiced support or opposition. Likewise, none of these landowners hold any notable public office or leadership role, indicating no high-influence neighbors in the community. None of the five adjacent landowners have a documented public stance regarding the development, with all classified as "unknown" in the absence of any stated support or opposition. Their community influence appears limited — none hold public office or leadership roles, and only one family (the Stoeltings) has notable long-term local ties that might confer moderate social influence. Two neighboring landowners were identified: a local veterinarian couple and an absentee co-owner of a family-held parcel. Neither has a recorded public stance on development (0 support, 0 oppose, 2 unknown). One neighbor (the vet couple) holds medium community influence as local professionals, while the other (absent landowner) has low influence. The neighboring entities are long-established family farming corporations that hold significant acreage in Harlan County, NE. Murdoch Enterprises Inc. (led by the Murdoch family) and James Drake Farm Enterprises LLC (owned by the Drake family) are primarily engaged in corn and grain agriculture. Neither appears to be a commercial developer; their interests lie in farming, though the Murdochs’ local leadership role could translate into influence over any development proposals. Potential risks include these landowners opposing projects that threaten their land use or water resources, but conversely they could support or partner in developments that provide financial benefits without harming their farm operations.
